description:
Oenanthe melanoleuca, commonly known as the White-crowned Wheatear, is a species of bird belonging to the genus Oenanthe, which is part of the family Muscicapidae. This small, migratory passerine bird is native to regions of the Middle East and Central Asia.

The species is characterized by its distinctive black and white plumage, with a prominent white crown, black face, and black wings and tail. The male and female birds exhibit similar coloration, although the females may have a slightly duller appearance.

Oenanthe melanoleuca primarily inhabits arid and semi-arid environments, such as rocky hillsides, deserts, and high-altitude grasslands. These birds feed primarily on insects, including beetles, grasshoppers, and ants, which they often catch by perching on rocks or low vegetation and making short flights to capture their prey.

The breeding season for Oenanthe melanoleuca typically occurs during the spring and summer months, with the birds constructing nests in rock crevices or cavities. The females lay a clutch of 4-6 eggs, which they incubate for approximately 13-15 days. The hatchlings are then cared for by both parents until they are able to fledge and become independent.

The conservation status of Oenanthe melanoleuca is classified as Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as the species has a widespread distribution and a stable population size.
